content.title: The 5-Question Interview Prep
content.script:
Stop memorizing 100 behavioral questions. Master these 5 instead. By the end of this video, you'll have a framework that works for 90% of interviews...

Number 1: Tell me about yourself. Don't give your life story - focus on your last 3-5 years of relevant experience.

Number 2: Why this company? Show you've done research. Mention something specific about their culture or recent projects.

Number 3: Describe a challenge you've overcome. Use the STAR method: Situation, Task, Action, Result.

Number 4: Where do you see yourself in 5 years? Show ambition but stay realistic and aligned with the role.

Number 5: Do you have any questions for us? ALWAYS ask thoughtful questions. It shows genuine interest.

Practice these tonight and you'll crush your next interview!
keyPoints: Master 5 core questions that cover 90% of interviews
Adapt your stories to different question formats
content.imagePrompt: Professional woman in business suit and glasses, confident expression
content.bRollPrompt: Office environment, interview setting, professional atmosphere

content.title: Resume ATS Secrets
content.script:
Your resume is getting rejected before a human sees it? Here's why...

Most companies use ATS (Applicant Tracking Systems) to filter resumes. If your resume isn't ATS-friendly, it never reaches the hiring manager.

Secret 1: Use simple formatting. No tables, columns, or fancy graphics.

Secret 2: Include exact keywords from the job description. The ATS scans for these.

Secret 3: Use standard section headers: 'Work Experience', 'Education', 'Skills'.

Secret 4: Save as .docx or .pdf, never .jpg or .png.

Secret 5: Test your resume with an ATS checker online before applying.

Fix these 5 things and watch your response rate skyrocket!
keyPoints: Beat the ATS system with simple formatting
Use standard file formats and headers
content.imagePrompt: Professional woman reviewing resume on laptop, focused expression
content.bRollPrompt: Office desk, computer screen showing resume, professional setting

content.title: Salary Negotiation Framework
content.script:
Never accept the first offer. Here's my 3-step framework that's helped people get 10-30% more...

Step 1: Pause. When they make an offer, say 'Thank you, I'm excited! Can I have 24 hours to review?'

Step 2: Research. Check Glassdoor, Levels.fyi, and talk to people in similar roles. Know your worth.

Step 3: Counter with confidence. 'Based on my research and the value I bring, I was hoping for $X. Is there flexibility?'

Pro tip: Always give a specific number, not a range. Ranges make you seem uncertain.

And NEVER mention your previous salary unless legally required.

Use this framework and you'll negotiate like a pro!
keyPoints: Never accept the first offer immediately
Counter with specific numbers, not ranges
content.imagePrompt: Professional woman in negotiation meeting, confident posture
content.bRollPrompt: Corporate meeting room, professional handshake, business setting

content.title: LinkedIn Profile Optimization
content.script:
Your LinkedIn profile is costing you opportunities. Fix these 5 things today...

1. Headline: Don't just list your job title. Use this formula: What you do + Who you help + Your impact. Example: 'Helping tech startups scale | Product Manager | Launched 10+ features reaching 1M+ users'

2. Photo: Use a professional headshot with good lighting. No selfies, no group photos.

3. About section: Tell your story in first person. Make it conversational, not a resume copy-paste.

4. Experience: Focus on results, not responsibilities. Use numbers whenever possible.

5. Custom URL: linkedin.com/in/yourname looks way more professional than those random numbers.

Make these changes and watch your profile views double!
keyPoints: Use professional photo and custom URL
Write about section in first person with personality
content.imagePrompt: Professional woman working on laptop, LinkedIn on screen
content.bRollPrompt: Modern office, laptop showing LinkedIn profile, professional workspace

content.title: Email Subject Lines That Get Opened
content.script:
Your emails are going straight to spam. Here's why...

Most people use boring subject lines like 'Following Up' or 'Quick Question'.

Instead, use these proven formulas:

Formula 1: [Name] → [Name], this will interest you
Formula 2: [Specific Value] → '3 ideas to improve your conversion rate'
Formula 3: [Mutual Connection] → 'Sarah Johnson suggested I reach out'
Formula 4: [Urgency + Value] → 'Limited spots: Free marketing audit for your company'

The key? Be specific, be relevant, be brief.

And never use all caps or exclamation marks in professional emails!!!

Start using these and watch your open rates soar!
keyPoints: Use proven formulas with specific value
content.imagePrompt: Professional woman composing email, focused on laptop
content.bRollPrompt: Office desk, email composition screen, professional environment
